text: with the Supreme Court striking down the
Defense of Marriage Act a lot will
change but a lot won't many federal laws
and benefits that married straight
couples have long enjoyed will be
extended to married gay couples many gay
spouses will be able to receive Social
Security benefits jointly file their
federal income taxes and share health
care plans without a tax penalty that
could add up to thousands of dollars a
month gay spouses will be able to
inherit without paying federal taxes
that issue was at the center of the case
the court decided gay foreigners married
to Americans will be able to petition
for green cards allowing them to stay
and work in the country but the court's
decision will not change everything a
whole swath of laws is determined by the
states including marriage and activists
are warning gay couples not to expect
benefits immediately because government
agencies have varied rules currently 38
states do not allow same-sex marriage
and since the IRS and the Social
Security Administration look at the
state where a couple lives not where
they got married gay married couples in
those states won't be eligible for
benefits other agencies like the
Department of Defense look at where a
couple is married regardless of where
they live now the same-sex spouse of a
service member would get health care
benefits no matter where the couple
lives the job of sorting much of this
out will now fall to the Obama
administration they have a series of
complicated and politically sensitive
decisions ahead about how to adjust
federal rules to comply with the court's
decision
